Award.AwardTitle: UNS: The Effect of Flow-Induced Concentration Inhomogeneities on the Flow of Polymer Solutions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510333(Leal)

It has been found that during the processing of complex fluids, such as polymer and surfactant solutions, liquid crystals, etc., large molecules in the solution can migrate to more concentrated areas. The goal of the proposed research is to understand this phenomenon, known as shear-induced banding, for the case of polymers. Discovering the fundamental reasons for this phenomenon has significant technological implications in processing and manufacturing of complex fluids that are common in the petrochemical, consumer products and the food industry.

When a macromolecular suspension (e.g., surfactants, polymers, and possibly proteins) is sheared, there is what is known as stress-induced migration of the macromolecules or micelles toward regions of higher concentration of the solution, via the so-called Helfand Fredrickson (HF) mechanism. In this work, the co-PIs propose to explore whether this mechanism can produce macroscopic concentration gradients in polymer solutions - a case where this phenomenon is somewhat controversial. The co-PIs, through prior theoretical work, have suggested that the coupling between the polymer stress and concentration in entangled solutions produces a linear instability for simple shear flow, and this instability leads to shear banding. In this proposal, they propose a coordinated experimental and computational approach to investigate this problem, and then to generalize the results to other flows: (a) pressure driven flow in a tube which exhibits a "spurt" instability, and (b) flow in 2- and 4-roll milling flows, i.e., testing their models under different stress patterns and even extensional flows. The proposed approach will involve both careful experiments (using rheo-NMR and neutron scattering) and computations. Outreach and dissemination of research is planned, involving graduate students in research. In addition, results will be disseminated to the industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed an important phenomenon that has been reported to occur when complex fluids undergo a simple shear flow; namely, that the velocity profiles have an unexpected form in which different regions experience different shear rates even though the stress remains uniform. This phenomenon is known as shear banding, and can be critical to processing, and to the interpretation of rheological experiments that are needed to characterize the mechanical properties of such materials. Although some experiments show that this phenomenon occurs in polymer solutions, many researchers have indicated that this is not possible for that very important type of complex fluid. In this grant, we showed theoretically that concentrated polymer solutions can develop macroscopic concentration non-uniformities in flow and that this provides a mechanism for shear banding to occur, as well as being a major concern for processing since it could lead to products with spatial variations in material properties. More importantly than developing a theory, however, we developed an experimental system to test the predictions of the theory. By means of particle tracking methods and the use of fluorescence imaging of polymer molecules that were labelled with a fluorescent tag, we were able to demonstrate that the predictions of the theory actually occur in practice. Specifically, we found that the concentration profiles in a simple flow device became "banded"--i.e. different concentrations in different parts of the flow, and that this led to banded velocity profiles in quantitative agreeconcentrated ("entangled")ment with the theory. So far as we are aware, this is the first experimental verification of flow induced concentration non-uniformities in concentrated polymer solutions. Furthermore, we were able to experimentally show that it was also possible for even flow enhanced concentration fluctuations to lead to significant changes in the flow--for systems where the effects of flow-induced "migration" are too weak to lead to macroscopic banding, microscopic flow enhanced concnetration fluctuations can still produce important changes in the flow behavior of the fluid. Our work provides the first evidence for this conclusion, even though flow enhanced fluctuations were first discovered nearly 30 years ago.

From a more general point of view, the most important long-term outcome of this work may be the theoretical framework that we have developed for the analysis of the flow behavior of concentrated, entangled polymer solutions. It is almost always assumed in predicting the flow/processing behavior of polymeric fluids that the material remains uniform in the presence of flow--i.e. that the concentration of polymer is the same everywhere in a flow. The specific problem we have studied here shows that this is not necessarily the case. Specifically, this work shows that the most basic assumption of exsting non-Newtonian fluid mechanics investigations and predictions of flow, including processing flows, is not generally correct. Beyond this, and more importantly, we have developed a new theoretical framework that should be used and can be adopted by others for prediction of the flow behavior of polymer solutions. Finally, we have also developed an experimental protocol that can also be used by others to determine whether a particular flow exhibits spatial inhomogeneity or not.
